title: Consumer Cos Down on Fears About U.S.-China Deal — Consumer Roundup
text:
Shares of retailers and other consumer-services companies fell amid fears that the U.S. and China would not reach a deal in November as previously anticipated.

Economists warn that tariffs could soon put upward pressure on consumer inflation.

Average national home prices grew 3.2% in the year ending in August, according to data released Tuesday by the S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller National Home Price Index, up slightly from 3.1% the prior month.

Shares of Kellogg rose after the food processor posted earnings above Wall Street expectations, as demand for snacks such as Pringles and Cheez-it offset a consumer shift away from breakfast cereals, sales of which fell by almost 5% in North America.

Ford Motor said it's recalling about 320,000 vehicles in North America for various safety reasons.

Embattled e-cigarette maker Juul Labs appointed a new chief financial officer, Guy Cartwright, as finance chief, succeeding Tim Danaher, who had asked to leave the company.

Write to Rob Curran at rob.curran@dowjones.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

October 29, 2019 17:08 ET (21:08 GMT)
